title: Standardize and Upgrade 10.9
body:
### Status 12/31/2014
* OS X 10.9 Mavericks is current; recommended Mavericks upgrades have not been done
* some recommended tasks from previous OS X versions were not completed
* we have also learned a lot in some areas, especially testing, that we need to implement

This issue collects multiple github issues relating to these items for planning, organizing and tracking.



##### Upgrade History Files
#3 adopt GitHub Issues and Markdown

##### Rebuild Projects

##### Backup and Maintenance
#4 establish and implement full backup procedure



- [ ] #7 establish Objective-C coding standards
#8 establish stronger compiler error recognition
#9 organize Objective-C code consistently
#10 implement Private Categories
#11 testing: code coverage tool
#12 modernize Objective-C
#13 profile with Instruments
#16 distribution and entitlements
#17 implement scheduled maintenance
#20 upgrade LLDB debugging support
#21 git workflow support
#22 convert scripts ccInstall and archive to Python
#23 rebuild simpler Xcode projects
#24 improve TechnicalDocs upload
#25 add Finder target
#29 Mavericks
#30 Convert to ARC
#31 Python and Workflow support
#32 Doxygen install script generates config file
carolclark/Punkin#2 configure for AppStore
carolclark/Punkin#5 refactor for testability
carolclark/Punkin#6 handle PaintCode files
carolclark/Accessor#5 adopt a C++ unit testing tool
carolclark/Accessor#6 secure automation
carolclark/Accessor#7 upgrade C++ wrapper classes to use ivars
carolclark/Accessor#8 migrate to ARC

title: Doxygen install script generates config file
body: Doxygen config files currently rely on Developer directory at ${HOME}/Dev

title: Python and Workflow support
body:
* *Python appears a better choice than unix for producing robust, testable shell scripts; see also #18 "clean up UNIX error handling"*
* *Python also is used to customize LLDB, and has the capability to be extended in embedded in a way that looks practical as a way to replace the Rez language as a way to define Slates in Accessor.*
* *Cdoc html files were placed in a separate folder to accommodate ccInstall's limitations. Those files are now harder to preview because the source folder has a different structure from the target site.*

We will set up an environment for working in Python, and use that environment to make some initial improvements and corrections to our developer workflow.

see [Python for Bash Scripters](http://magazine.redhat.com/2008/02/07/python-for-bash-scripters-a-well-kept-secret/), [A Clean Python Shell Script](http://www.jperla.com/blog/post/a-clean-python-shell-scrip), [Python Tutorial](http://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/), [Python in Xcode](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5276967/python-in-xcode-4-or-xcode-5), [Python Unit Testing Framework](http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html), [GitPython](http://pythonhosted.org/GitPython/0.3.1/tutorial.html#and-even-more).

### Python start
- [x] initial Python project with test

### Workflow
- [ ] merge_message
- [ ] extract function ccdev.parse_cmdline
- [ ] scm.changes: diff --name-status and lg for arg1..arg2 (eg. "changes master current_branch") 
- [ ] Slates: FileMerge handles non-ascii dialog; Python subslate with def's for functions and tests
- [ ] ?add ccdev.dir, ccdev.help - shell command-line versions of python dir, help
    * *Python's built-in help is marginally usable due to the need to constantly change directories and to figure out what module is needed from an excessive list in order to look up something. Try to wrap the commands in a useable script.*

##### Find "git" issue
* ccInstall findSources tries to skip directory".git", but actually skips all files containing "git"

* *example showing how to skip hidden files does not work as advertised; we found a way to filter out the ".git" files at the grep stage instead that worked from Terminal, but still failed from the script*
- [ ] Python function find_source_files (path)

title: Convert to ARC
body:
* *garbage collection now deprecated - *What's New in Xcode 13#400@29:00*
* see also Modern Objective-C 12#405, Adopting Automatic Reference Counting 12#406*
* see also carolclark/Accessor#8 :migrate to ARC

title: Mavericks
body:
### Xcode 5
see *What's New in Xcode 13#400*
##### Install and Switch
- [x] rename Xcode 4 app; install Xcode 5 alongside
- [x] switch to Xcode 5
- [x] update all projects and targets for compatiblity with Xcode 5
- [x] automation: smaller toolbar; new documentation window; Source control is its own menu;adjust for added navigator; nav kb shortcut should now enable arrow selection

##### Adopt Standard Features
- [x] Source Control 4:40
    * configure source control 5:00
    * consider how branch support fits in
- [x] Asset catalog 9:25
    * Move existing content into new asset catalog 13:15
- [x] Doc comments 27:20
- [ ] use modules to replace/augment pch files in ObjC projects 22:20
- [x] Debugging
    * Debug bar, except layouts 32:00
    * Debug gauges 32:50
- [x] Test navigator 44:30

### Mavericks

### Continuous Integration

*see "What's New in Xcode" 13#400@44:30

*iOS 6 will continue to require OCUnit; Xcode has a tool to migrate to XCTest when that is no longer an issue

### iOS and Interface Builder
* *Punkin: initial Nanny for iOS*
- [ ] Auto config - provisioning 5:20
- [ ] Interface design 7:30
- [ ] Interface preview: select from assistant jumpbar 16:20
- [ ] Turn on auto layout 17:20
- [ ] Debug bar layout support 32:00

title: add Finder target
body:
recover script toTEXT; include documentation for changing creator and/or file type

on open filelist
	tell application "Finder"
		repeat with onefile in filelist
			set file type of onefile to "TEXT"
		end repeat
	end tell
end open

on run
	choose file with prompt "Select one or more files to convert to TEXT format:" with multiple selections allowed
	open (the result as list)
end run

title: improve TechnicalDocs upload
body:
* upload TechnicalDocs website
    * switch from Cyberduck (not scriptable; in Java; quirky and/or buggy) to Transmit ($34 app; solid; good support; routinely enhanced/improved)
    * add Upload (activates/uses Transmit) to workflow at Xcode's ValidateHTML slate

    * *see also unix scp command*

title: rebuild simpler Xcode projects
body:
*Xcode project files are fragile and easily corrupted.  According to forum discussions, corrupted project files sometimes require rebuilding from scratch, and contain information that is not saved elsewhere.*
*The problem is compounded by version control, since any change to the files or settings of a project causes the project to be changed, and therefore possibly subject to merge conflicts. This is of particular concern for Punkin, which has an Artist collaborator.*
*We set the git attributes for project files to `merge=union`, which helps but does not solve the problem.*

* minimize dependence on information stored in project files
    * use configuration files to replace most build settings
    * document each Repository's Projects, Targets and dependencies
* use modules to replace pch files (ObjC only?) *What's New in Xcode 5 13#400@22:20*

see  [Merging Xcode project files](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4022362/merging-xcode-project-files), [Google example config files](http://code.google.com/p/google-toolbox-for-mac/source/browse/trunk/XcodeConfig/), [Easy, Modular: Static Libraries and Cross-Project References](http://www.clintharris.net/2009/iphone-app-shared-libraries/)

body:
* *Python appears a better choice for producing robust, testable shell scripts; see also #18 "clean up UNIX error handling"*
* *Python also is used to customize LLDB, and has the capability to be extended in embedded in a way that looks practical as a way to replace the Rez language as a way to define Slates in Accessor.*
* *Cdoc html files were placed in a separate folder to accommodate ccInstall's limitations. Those files are now harder to preview because the source folder has a different structure from the target site.*

see [Python for Bash Scripters](http://magazine.redhat.com/2008/02/07/python-for-bash-scripters-a-well-kept-secret/), [A Clean Python Shell Script](http://www.jperla.com/blog/post/a-clean-python-shell-script)

- [ ] [Python Tutorial](http://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/)

title: git workflow support
body:
see [How to avoid these merge commits in the future](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6406762/why-am-i-merging-remote-tracking-branch-origin-develop-into-develop), [A few git tips you didn't know about](http://mislav.uniqpath.com/2010/07/git-tips/), [github/hub](https://github.com/github/hub)

*11/02/2013 github/hub not used for now; what we know well enough to abbreviate, we already automate; Tips has some additional ideas that might be useful later*

#### Add to Accessor Slates
*From [A few git tips you didn't know about](http://mislav.uniqpath.com/2010/07/git-tips/)*
- [ ] add --decorate to lg alias to included tags, and possibly additional branch information
- [ ] add --word-diff option to diff; document
- X (Made unnecessary by git version 1.8.3.4, installed with Xcode 5) pushing branches with tracking
    * add --set-upstream (establish tracking) to push options 
    * git config --global push.default tracking - to push only the current branch
    * document
- [ ] add --track to checkout options; document
- [ ] add name-rev to show where among tags a specific commit was made; document

#### Additional Scripting and Alias support
- [ ] refactor: for all unix files, includes come before help info to keep file's help from being overwritten by that from includes
- [ ] handle items for which Slates now enter scripts (eg. diff/list)
    * branch / getCurrent
    * tag / annotate
    * difference / (specs) / listFiles; selectFile
- [ ] customize terminal prompt with git branch
    * see [Put Your Git Branch in Your Bash Prompt](http://code-worrier.com/blog/git-branch-in-bash-prompt/)

title: upgrade LLDB debugging support
body: see Xcode 4.6 Release Notes, wwdc12#412 Debugging in Xcode. wwdc12#415 Debugging in LLDB

title: migrate Cdoc from HTML/sed to Markdown
body:
###### *Current Cdoc: existing in-house system for producing website for technical documentation*
* *created several years ago to simplify some aspects, especially accessibility features, for our in-house documentation*
* *currently uses a `sed`-based mechanism for expanding special features; JavaScript would be better*
* *current Cdoc history files do not scale well, especially for multiple developers, and represent a large investment in attempting to track what we're doing, with limited success*

###### *Markdown: publicly-available perl script to produce web content from readable text files*
* *much simpler and more collaborator-friendly*
* *can contain embedded HTML*
* *translators are available to convert markdown to HTML and HTML to markdown*
* *GitHub uses `markdown` for text rendering; Cdoc uses HTML. For collaborator-friendly editing, `markdown` provides a huge advantage compared with HTML.*

##### Conclusion
* History files: simplify and adapt toward simpler content to synchronize with Issues; see issue #3
* over time, implement special features in css and JavaScript for Markdown as well as `sed` translation
    * Markdown files can include HTML content, but Cdoc HTML features will be supported only from Cdoc HTML files
* eventually, convert existing Cdoc source to markdown
    * see [Markdown Tools][mdTools] and/or Markdownify for conversion from HTML

[mdTools]: http://brettterpstra.com/projects/markdown-service-tools
[markdownCdocNotes]: #MarkdownCdoc

Tasks:
* backup github issues
* support daily builds and testing with Continuous Integration tools (CI requires Xcode 5, Mavericks, OS X Server)

        * see list of tools in 12#404: Building from the Command Line 22:23; also see environment variable for developer directory 25:55 

see:

[cron basics](http://www.tldp.org/LDP/intro-linux/html/sect_04_04.html)
[cron email](http://www.nixtutor.com/linux/sending-email-alerts-through-cron//)

title: testing: code coverage tool
body:
Consider adoption

See [How to Measure Code Coverage in Xcode](http://qualitycoding.org/xcode-code-coverage/)

title: implement Private Categories
body:
Use Category Private, in a separate header included in both implementation and unit test files, to support Unit Testing while keeping private information private. See [Unit testing of private methods in Xcode](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1098550/unit-testing-of-private-methods-in-xcode)
See also #9

title: organize Objective-C code consistently
body: see [Code Organization in Xcode Projects](http://akosma.com/2009/07/28/code-organization-in-xcode-projects/) (akosma), #10

title: establish stronger compiler error recognition
body:
enable recognition of most compiler errors; treat warnings as errors
see [Objective-C Compiler Warnings](http://akosma.com/2009/07/16/objective-c-compiler-warnings/), and [Confusing Objective-C Warnings and Errors](http://www.cocoawithlove.com/2009/04/8-confusing-objective-c-warnings-and.html) for additional advice

title: establish Objective-C coding  standards
body:
*We now have enough experience with Objective-C to have an idea which advice to take.*

* Establish initial standards; [akosma](http://wiki.akosma.com/Objective-C_Code_Standards) is probably a good starting point.
    * Use Category Private, in a separate header included in both implementation and unit test files, to support Unit Testing while keeping private information private. See [Unit testing of private methods in Xcode](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1098550/unit-testing-of-private-methods-in-xcode)

[O'Reilly Webcast: Developing Effective OCUnit and UI Automation Testing for iOS](http://m.youtube.com/watch?v=5SycebOn7iY&desktop_uri=%2Fwatch%3Fv%3D5SycebOn7iY) (Code coverage at 21:20)

title: consider making Doxygen and Cdoc docs available from GitHub
body: see [Use Doxygen with GitHub]@(http://rickfoosusa.blogspot.com/2011/10/howto-use-doxygen-with-github.html)

title: establish and implement full backup procedure
body:
Update backup support procedures, including usage of our external volumes
    * see QuickPicks: our current backup utility, obtained from MobileMe, identifies critical data for some standard applications; it looks like a good list
    * Backup itself - Is it still usable under 10.9?

title: adopt GitHub Issues and Markdown
body: see [Marked](http://markedapp.com) editing app - [x] [begin] begin using GitHub Issues; synchronize with History files (Support; Punkin; Accessor) * History file: begin to adapt toward simpler content to synchronize with Issues; use HTML `pre` tag to simulate markdown text * *see [Markdown / Cdoc Notes][MarkdownCdocNotes]* - [x] [backup] backup GitHub issue content * `curl --user "carolclark:gh6868cc" https://api.github.com/issues` gets assigned issues * `curl --user "carolclark:gh6868cc" https://api.github.com/repos/carolclark/Accessor/issues` gets open issues - [x] script to backup open issues for each project to Issues.json in project's root folder and for all projects to /Aux/GitHubIssues.json - [ ] add repository argument; update Issues for that repository only - [x] support documentation editing in BBEdit * use Marked to preview Markdown output * *BBEdit preview does not work for Markdown* - [ ] use a separate file to contain history for each version * *eg. Support_v0_1.html for work on v0.1; probably also includes bugfix versions 0.1.1, etc.* - [ ] allow markdown files to be included in the source for Cdoc sites * cInstall: Cdoc translation also handles markdown source * make sure valid HTML is produced - [ ] switch history files to markdown - [ ] create new issues for future plans from existing History.html files see also #19 migrate from HTML/sed to Markdown for further Markdown work
